reviewText: I recently purchased the DVD from eBay.  It is from China, but it is universally coded for all DVD players. I used to go to the Saturday afternoon cinema back in the late 70's and Bugsy Malone was one of the enduring favorites. This is probably the best acting performance by Scott Baio, this after having viewed Zapped a few times. I love the songs, and even when I saw the movie for the first time in I don't know how long, I remembered a majority of the words. So it did leave a lasting impression on me.

reviewText: Okay, if you saw the film, you understand the title. This film is best seen with other with children or if you saw it as a child yourself (as I did in 1976). I recall enjoying relating to the kids on the screen and wishing I was onscreen with them, as children living in their own world is the ultimate kid fantasy. To the editorial reviewers-some films cannot be judged by adult standards, see it through the eyes of your inner child.
summary: We could've been anything that we wanted to be!

reviewText: The Chinese writing/Jodie Foster cover is kind of funny/weird but still, it's the same movie I saw as a kid. After reading some reviews here I find that people either love or hate this movie. I love it because it's part of my childhood. My brother and I saw it in the mid-seventies when I was around 6 and the songs stuck with us for life. He told me he often sings "So You Wanna Be a Boxer" while working and no one ever gets the reference. It is obscure but shouldn't be. Aside from the two big stars that would come out of it the movie is amazingly well done for it's time. The sets, dance routines, props (how about those pedal powered limos!), costumes and unforgettable music suggest that the producers really put their hearts into it. Yes, they plagerize mobster films to the tee but that's the point- a true children's world: Instead of brains splattering on a wall when someone is shot in the face they are litterally "creamed" with custard; steamy sex is replaced by sweet pecks and hugs, and the "big shoot out" that left a bloody mess in "Scarface" is replaced here with a food fight, singing, dancing and brotherhood. Wouldn't it be cool if the world were really like that? Maybe not to some, but to those who can see things with children's eyes it might.Yeah, some adults may find some of this creepy, particularly the girls dancing around like Jon Benet Ramsey in short shorts, but remember this movie was made in 1976 before Ramsey, before the "tweens" ware a market or even a word, before the Britney and Lohan melt-downs, before reality only existed on TV, before children's cartoons needed parental guidance, before having to keep up with the Kardashians, before everyone felt you really didn't mind hearing their cell phone conversation, before personal computers, before paparazzi killed Diana, before the terrorists slammed into the twin towers, before Bush declared war on the world and mission accomplished and before $4/gallon gas. It was a nice time to be around for most five/six year olds and this movie takes me back. For that, it gets five stars.

reviewText: This is a great movie based on a really cute concept (child actors playing adult roles). It's certainly interesting to see a young Jodie Foster.It's interesting that this UK import region free Blu-ray is selling for $33 (as of Jan. 2009) because you can order it directly from Amazon UK for about $15. Yes, the shipping will be more expensive, but not by that much.A note on the region free element. The movie is region free, but the special features are in PAL and therefore will not play on a U.S. Blu-ray player.
summary: Great movie with a cute concept
Title: N/A

reviewText: This fabulous oddity from director Alan Parker is the stuff of legend here in the US, as it has not been available commercially, and is no longer seen even in late night TV viewings.  Since almost everyone who did see it when it was released back in the 1970s, or anyone who somehow saw it in later years, remembers it fondly, there seems no good reason why it has been so hard to come by here;  the only explanation possible must be the American sensitivity about pedophilia, and a resulting uneasiness toward the film by those who choose what to release as ancillary product.  Luckily, this all region blu-ray is now available, and it's worth the price.  The quality is very good, and the disc plays without any problem in my standard Region A player.
summary: A Pre-pubescent Gem From a More Innocent Time

reviewText: It's unusual how they come up with a movie like this and yet it gets good results for the cuteness of it and we wonder why it takes so long for a movie this old to get re-released on DVD or VHS or any format because people want it so bad.  You look at some of the names and wonder who the heck they are.  First off you know who Scott Baio is, you know who Jodie Foster is, but who in the world is FLORRIE DUGGER, JOHN CASSI?  When I first saw this movie it was an amazing sight to see that the singing numbers were "lip-sync'd".  You'd think that Scott Baio at that age could've actually sang or Jodie Foster actually singing "My Name is Talula" or the janitor singing "Tomorrow".  The one number I thought was interesting was the "Fat Sam Speakeasy" dance number where the teenage black kid WITH PAUL WILLIAMS voice on it.  In case you did not know, Paul Williams musical talents played a big part in all this.  And you know right away when that black teenage boy starts singing, that it is NOT his real voice it is Paul Williams voice.  The funny parts you'll see are the parts where they have the Splurge guns that shoot thawed out biscuits courtesy of NABISCO.  Yes the National Biscuit Company AKA Nabisco furnishes the thawed out biscuits that they shot at each other and the pie fight scene at the end.  This movie has promised to come out "IN AMERICA" on DVD since April 11th but it never went through it is however on DVD over seas in some foreign countries as an import but it is I am told able to be ordered on here cause it is in english.  Well anyway, I hope Paramount puts it out on DVD in America cause that would be awesome!!!!!  Just think Scott Baio came a long way from doing this to being Chachie (not sure on spelling) to Charles and now kind of taking it easy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bugsy Malone is a one-of-a-kind movie in that it is a musical performed entirely by actors 16 or under, and most were 13 or under. Words and music are by popular composer Paul Williams, but all of the singing was dubbed by adults.Great photography and art direction, too.Although acted by kids, this is not a juvenile movie. It could easily be made with adults with very little changes.The movie is framed as a late-20's gangster movie, and includes turf wars fought with cream-shooting "splurge" guns, period clothes and 1920's style cars (OK, they are pedal-powered but with regular sound), and tough talk (for kids, anyway).Jodie Foster and Scott Baio are the biggest names, and surprisingly, for the most part the other actors did very little work after this movie.Full of subtle and not so subtle humor, the movie should entertain nearly anyone. No doubt it was a logistical nightmare (tutors, child labor laws, etc) so one should give director Alan Parker extra credit for the concept for one of his earliest efforts.Jodie Foster has a great line - "I like my men at my feet" - worthy of Mae West.

reviewText: I first saw this film as a child at the matinees. For years I held on to random memories of what I had seen knowing for certain only the title of this picture, Bugsy Malone, and that the cast was all kids. One day two years ago, I found a copy in the store and had to buy it. Previously, I had never seen a copy anywhere and hadn't seen it since the original viewing. Watching it for the second time was an experience I can't even discribe. It brought back scenes I didn't know I remembered. This movie is one of my favorites. When I've worn the tape out, I will rebuy it. My hope is that it will be released on DVD soon.
summary: A classic discovered all over again! Bravo!

reviewText: We all have our guilty pleasures..."Bugsy Malone" is three or four of mine.Yep, it's a strange one...a gangster musical with a cast 13 and under. But the kids are having a ball, the period setting is fantastic, the songs are catchy, and some numbers...particularly the "Down and Out" bit...are riotous and exhilarating. I say, put "Bugsy Malone" back in theaters. It's miles better than most of the crappy kids fare out these days. Hey, it might give Scott Baio's career a shot in the arm as well.
summary: So Ya Wanna be a Boxer?

reviewText: This was a popular film when it first came out, featuring a young Jodie Foster around the time of Taxi Driver and Scott Baio from the TV series Happy Days. Alan Parker, an excellent director, did pick an offbeat way of handing this film...tell a gangster story similar to old WB movies, but with musical numbers (by Paul Williams) and kids in all the adult roles.It was amusing to see it again, but a lot of the charm has worn off, and Parker in his commentary said he was seeing it again for the first time in about 20 years and that he considers it basically absurd.The UK Blu import plays the feature perfectly but none of the extras, which are recorded in PAL.The picture quality isn't much for this Blu release, lacking sharpness, but then the original wasn't any greater shakes to begin with. The sound quality is good.I'd recommend passing on ordering this title.
summary: Popular movie for its time, hasn't aged well
Title: N/A

reviewText: Finally a terrfic transfer of an absolute classic, I hadn't seen this since a matinee showing back in the 80s when I was a kid and now I see why an audience full of children practically rioted when they witnessed this.  A kids flick that doesn't talk down to the youngsters but throws them smack dab into an adult world, couple that with Paul Williams wonderfully catchy tunes and you have cinematic magic.  Jodi Foster and Scott Baio are odd, funny and interesting to watch and the kid who camps it up as the Fat Sam is brilliant.  I always felt like Alan Parker doesn't quite get his due considering the other classics he has been involved in this is just more fuel to that fire.  Transfer and audio quality are all top notch, just don't try to watch the extras on a Reg 1 player.
summary: Region 0 hi def transfer of a lost classic

reviewText: OK, I first saw this when my brother's school did a production of it and I was hooked.  I love the music, I love the lines, and I love most of the characters - basically, the whole film!  Why? -partly because it is funny,  partly because I'm interested in the 1920s anyway, and partly because you  know you aren't going to get loads of blood and gore in it.  I admit that  it could be seen as a bit perverted seeing little girls dressed up as  speakeasy dancers, but the whole point is that it's a scaled-down version  of a gangster movie - you can't have adults shooting each other with  custard, it wouldn't work.  (And besides, you can find perversion in lots  of things.)  Basically, if you're a bit squeamish and want something safe  but great, rent this!  (And it's v. interesting seeing the young Michael  Jackson as the piano player.)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Just a quick review about the iTV Studios Blu-ray...As another reviewer mentioned, the movie and commentary play fine, with a 5.1 soundtrack that sounds great and the picture quality is great as well, but none of the Extras will play at all, due to the UK format.  I don't think it's PAL though, but maybe 50i?  I'm not an audiophile, so I'm not sure of the format.But if you want this film on blu-ray, it's worth $16, IMO, until Paramount finally releases it in the u.s.  But even then, I would seriously doubt that these extras would be included.  Just a hunch.As for the movie itself, it's really a film for those who grew up with it, like me. In fact, it's the first film I ever remember seeing in the theater (I was 4 years old :-).  Because truthfully, I'm not sure this film holds up for anyone seeing it for the first time, now.  For example, a friend of mine saw it (even several years ago) just laughed after it was over and called it "corny as hell".  And the acting isn't really great from all parties - specifically the actress who plays Blousey Brown.  Terrible performance.  In fact, if I'm totally honest, she basically ruins every scene she's in.  However the other main actors are good enough, especially young Jodie Foster of course.Overall, though, I love it.  I love the splurge guns.  I love the fact that it's an all kids cast acting as gangster adults.  I love just about every song from the uber-talented Paul Williams, especially "Bad Guys", "Fat Sam's Grand Slam", "So You Wanna Be a Boxer", "Down and Out" and the finale "You Give a Little Love".  This is one of those movies that takes me back to the place in my life when I saw the film, and in this case, I was an innocent 4 year old boy.  :-)
